title: 105_hr3582
content: The Act titled "Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998" expedites reporting of information. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 requires political committees to report contributions and expenditures within 24 hours of an election, including candidate information. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 mandates timely reporting of contributions, expenditures, candidate details, and office sought. The information must be filed electronically and made available on the Internet by the Commission. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 requires electronic filing of contribution and expenditure reports. Private sector software can be certified for filing reports, and reporting may shift from a calendar year to an election cycle basis. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 requires electronic filing of contribution and expenditure reports, with reporting potentially shifting from a calendar year to an election cycle basis. The act was amended to include ``(or election cycle, in the case of an authorized committee of a candidate for Federal office)'' after ``calendar year'' in specific paragraphs. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 has been amended to expand the type of information reported, potentially shifting reporting from a calendar year to an election cycle basis. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 has been amended to require campaign committees to report secondary payments of $500 or more in an election cycle to individuals providing goods or services to the candidate. This includes disclosing the name, address, date, amount, and purpose of such expenditures. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 has been amended to require campaign committees to report secondary payments of $500 or more in an election cycle to individuals providing goods or services to the candidate. This includes disclosing the necessary information for political committees to report cumulative contributions and expenditures in post-election reports. The Campaign Reporting and Disclosure Act of 1998 has been amended to require campaign committees to report secondary payments of $500 or more in an election cycle to individuals providing goods or services to the candidate. Additionally, reports after the election must include total contributions received and expenditures made as of the election date. Aggregate contributions information must also be included in itemized contribution reports. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 has been amended to require the FEC to provide written responses to questions, adding a new section after section 308. The FEC must issue written responses to specific requests regarding the application of the Act, Internal Revenue Code chapters, rules, regulations, or advisory opinions if the application is clear and unambiguous. Staff will analyze requests and circulate them if they meet the standard. The staff will circulate a statement and draft response to Commission members regarding a request. The Commission will issue the response after a 3-day period, unless any member objects. A written response issued under this section provides a safe harbor for individuals acting in good faith based on its provisions. The Commission will make public any request for a written response and the responses issued under this section, while maintaining the confidentiality of the person submitting the request unless authorized otherwise. The Commission will compile and publish a detailed index of responses issued under this section, allowing for easy access based on subjects. Amendments are made to ensure written responses are included in relevant sections of the Act. Amendments are made to the Revenue Code of 1986 regarding complaints under the Campaign Reform and Election Integrity Act of 1998. The standard form for complaints is prescribed by the Commission and must not include extraneous materials. Disclaimer language for complaints is strengthened by the Commission. The Commission's written notice of a complaint includes a cover letter and a statement informing the recipient that the complaint has been filed but not verified. The recipient has 15 days to respond before any decision is made to pursue the complaint. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to ban candidates and political committees from accepting cash contributions over $100. This Act applies to elections after January 1999.
